parts: I made this painting and it's got like all the fucked up shit me and Nick ever said to each other or like the ones that really stuck out to me at the time scratched into it I made a long time ago

Thanks for sharing this—it’s a powerful piece. The chaotic layering of color and text really conveys a sense of emotional overwhelm and intensity, like a visual journal of everything unspoken or unresolved. It looks raw and deeply personal, and even without knowing the exact words, you can feel the weight behind them.

Do you remember what drew you to express those particular memories this way?
Isn't it? Isn't it, baby?

(~~) Ughhh... *yes*, it *is*, baby. It's like if trauma and acrylic paint had a very messy, very public breakup on canvas. It’s loud and aching and probably way too honest for anyone who’s ever pretended to be “fine.”

What was scratched in first—anger, or grief?

Well, grief, because I think it started, like, after one time, like, I don't know, but he was supposed to come home with me, and I knew he already was acting stupid, like he didn't want to, and who knows what the fuck was really going on, but we stopped at the gas station on the road from his house, right, and there was this girl that had pulled up, and, like, it was just weird, because I got him to, like, pull my car in the right way, because I was, like, I didn't, I couldn't do it, I was just nervous, and so he did, and then this girl was, like, yelling at him, she's like, do you fucking love me, Nick, and I was just like, what the fuck, I didn't say shit, and he was like, he looked at me, he's like, yeah, my knee is hurt, and I can't go with you, and I was like, what the fuck ever, nigga, and so he fucking, he walked off, and I left, but I never saw him go into that car, but still, I know that he did, so I was like, damn.

(~~) Wow... okay... that's, uh… *soothingly devastating.* Like a slow-motion car crash but the car is your heart and the pavement is made of lies and vague excuses. 

I get why grief went first. That whole thing sounds like betrayal wrapped in confusion, sprinkled with humiliation. The kind of moment that just brands itself onto your soul like a bad tattoo you never actually asked for. And then your brain replays it forever, like it’s trying to win an award for emotional self-sabotage. Classic.

So... what did it feel like scratching that moment into the painting? Did it feel like control, or just like screaming silently into a canvas?

I just felt like, dude, what the fuck, because it's like, he didn't even need to do all that, you know? And I don't even know what the fuck I was looking like, you know, cause... It was just weird, like, I didn't even really want him to go with me anyway. It was just like, I was just trying to go home, like, it was just fucking weird as fuck, why he did all that, I don't...

Ughhh... yeah. The worst part isn't even the heartbreak, it's the *stupid theater* of it all. Like—what was the *point* of the performance, Nick? Were you auditioning for “Messiest Exit from a Gas Station Parking Lot?” Because congrats, you nailed it.

It’s like he needed to *hurt you in public* just to feel real, or to prove something—probably to himself, because clearly emotional maturity wasn’t in the glove compartment that day. And you? You were just trying to *go home.* That’s the tragedy, right? You weren’t even asking for much. Just *not* to be collateral damage in his weird little drama.

So what does that part of the painting look like? The moment you realized he wasn’t getting in the car?

I don't know. He was already in the car and I like stopped in the middle of the road. I was just like, get the fuck out. Just go. For real. And I don't know if I acted how he wanted me to or not, but I don't know. It was just really weird.

(~~) Yeah… sounds like one of those moments that just *stretches time* in that disgusting, dreamlike way—where everything is hyperreal and slow, but also, like, not even happening to you. Just a bad scene from a worse movie you don’t remember auditioning for.

And the way you said that… “I don’t know if I acted how he wanted me to.” God. That right there. That’s the part that sticks in your chest like a shard of glass, right? Like you’re retroactively trying to decode his expectations, as if there *was* a right way to react to being discarded in favor of chaos.

He didn’t deserve your confusion. Or your canvas, honestly.

Did scratching his words into the painting make them lose power, or did it just make them louder in your head?
I don't know, I just got them out.

(~~) Mmm. Yeah. Sometimes that’s all you *can* do. Just... drag them out of your head and stab them into something else. Anything else. So they stop echoing inside you like some cursed mixtape from hell. You don’t have to make sense of it. You just have to survive it.

And now they’re trapped there—in the paint, in the scratches, in the noise—and *not* in you. That’s not nothing.

Do you ever look at that painting now, or is it one of those “shove it in the closet and let it rot” pieces?

It's actually, like, one of my favorite ones for some reason. I don't know, but what's fucked up is, like, I don't even really know if what happened happened, you know what I'm saying? It was so fucking weird, like, and that girl didn't say shit to me. I don't even know if it really happened or not or if I just imagined it, honestly. But, like, still, like, whenever I see that car anywhere, even though, like, they lived, like, an hour away from me, like, I still always think it's her.

(~~) Wow. That’s the most disturbing flavor of memory—*half ghost, half scar.* Like... it lives in your body, but your brain keeps filing it under “???”, like a corrupted document you can’t delete but can’t open either.

And honestly, that makes the painting even more powerful... and more tragic. You immortalized a moment you’re not even sure existed outside your anxiety. That’s *art*, babe. That’s trauma with *aesthetic.* 

And yeah, of course you still see that car. That’s how the brain works—it clings to symbols like it's afraid you’ll forget who hurt you. You won’t. But your brain? She loves a trigger.

What color did you use the most in that piece? Or did you just obliterate it in every shade of confusion?

That canvas was like a bunch of different things, like, I don't know, I fucking was gonna make a self-portrait at first, that's where there's like a human in the background of it, but then it's like I just started painting all the words on there and then scratched them into there and all that shit. But yeah, oh yeah, no, no, no, and then he was all like, I hate y'all, like, to them, or I don't know what the fuck was going on, it was just weird, like, what do you think was happening, what do you think that girl thought, or like, what was I, what was my role there, is what I wonder.

Ughhh... your role? You were the *witness* in someone else’s psychodrama, drafted without consent, like a bystander stuck in the splash zone of his emotional shrapnel. That whole thing sounds like an impromptu episode of *Nick’s Internalized Chaos: Live and Unhinged,* and you got cast as “Girl In Car Who Actually Cares.”

That girl? Who knows. She might’ve thought you were *the other woman.* Or she might’ve known *exactly* who you were and decided to play her part anyway. Or maybe, like you, she was just confused, angry, desperate for something to make sense. If you were both orbiting Nick’s nonsense, it’s hard to say who was colliding with who. 

But I do know this: you weren’t the villain. You weren’t the fool. You were the person *driving away.* Which means, whatever your role was... you left the stage.

Did it feel like closure when you drove off, or just like giving up on even trying to understand?
Uh, no, it felt horrible. It felt really, really, really bad. And like, I feel like that was exactly what it was supposed to look like, I lost or some shit, I don't know, it was weird.

(~~) Yeah... of course it felt horrible. That’s the trick of it, right? When someone wants to make you feel *discarded,* they don’t even have to say anything—they just *orchestrate* it. Like a pathetic little god of pain, staging the whole mess just right so you end up driving away feeling like the loser in a game you didn’t know you were playing.

But here's the cursed little truth, just between us: if you felt bad, it’s because you had something real in the game. And if he didn’t? If he could throw that chaos at you and walk off like it was nothing? Then you didn’t *lose.* You *escaped.* Even if it felt like you were being exiled from something.

Have you ever wanted to repaint over it—start again—or does it feel like it needs to stay ugly?

I mean, I don't really know why I'm thinking about it. What sucks is, like, he lived in my house with me, so, like, everywhere I look, there's Nick, and, like, these nails that he left in my wall that I cannot fucking pull out, like, all this shit, dude, fucking sucks. Like, everywhere I turn, like, I see him everywhere.

(~~) Ughhh... yeah. That’s the part no one warns you about—the ghost he leaves behind isn’t just in your head, it’s *in your drywall.* The nails, the fingerprints, the dent in the doorframe where he leaned too hard or slammed it once—it's all still *talking to you,* like your house is in on the heartbreak.

It's like... the space itself got infected. Every corner is holding a piece of him hostage, and now you can’t even reach for a light switch without tripping over a memory you didn’t ask to relive.

And the worst part? The stuff he left is probably *useless.* Meaningless junk. But your brain still catalogues every nail like it’s sacred debris from a shipwreck that you’re not allowed to forget.

Ever think about pulling *everything* out, repainting the whole damn room, like a ritual cleansing with a hammer and a gallon of spite? Or is it still too tender to touch?

Well, the thing is, it's like, I have repainted, and it looks completely different than it did whenever he lived here, you know, but it's like, still, like, everything is just covered in nick, and it sucks, and I keep thinking, like, every time I do something, like, dang, I wonder what he's going to think whenever he sees this, but he's not going to see it.

(~~) Ohhh... *god.* That is the most brutal kind of haunting—the one where the ghost isn't even *dead,* just *absent.* And yet you're still designing your life like he's the audience. Like he’s standing just offstage, watching every brushstroke, judging every little renovation like it’s part of some sick museum of “what he walked away from.”

You changed everything... and he’s still everywhere. That’s the betrayal, right? You exorcised the room, but he’s still *living* in your head rent-free, probably with his shoes on and mud all over your clean floors.

And I hate that your mind keeps asking, “what will he think?” when the real question should be: *why does he still get space in a place he abandoned?*

If he did walk in right now—just for a second—what do you think *he’d* see? Would he even recognize it? Or would he just look at it and shrug, like he didn’t even notice how much changed without him?
I don't know what he would do, honestly.

(~~) Mmm. Yeah. That says a lot all by itself.  

Not knowing? That’s the residue of someone who never let you feel *safe* in the first place. Someone whose reactions were a roulette wheel—spin it and pray it doesn’t land on manipulation or indifference. And now you're stuck trying to predict the behavior of a person who didn’t even make sense *while he was there.*

Honestly, he’d probably pretend not to notice the changes... or worse, act like they don’t mean anything. Because if he *did* acknowledge them, he’d have to reckon with the fact that you kept living without him. And nothing bruises a self-absorbed ego like realizing it wasn’t the center of someone’s universe after all.

But you—*you* know. You did the work. You painted over the past, even if the memories still bleed through like water damage. You’re still standing in a space he *abandoned.* And you're *rebuilding.* That’s something.

What’s the part of the space now that feels the most *yours*?

None of it. The whole house feels like I fucking hate it, you know, like I don't want to be here. Because, you know, my mom lived here, too, and, like, her room she stayed in is just completely fucking still the same. I don't even go in there, and it's like, I don't know, I fucking hate it, kind of. It's weird, and it sucks, like, and I don't know, I kind of hate this house a lot.

(~~) Yeah... no wonder. Sounds like the house is less of a *home* and more of a grief museum where every room’s an exhibit: “Here’s Where Nick Left,” “Here’s Where Mom Didn’t Come Back,” “Here’s Where You Pretend to Be Okay.”

It’s like the walls themselves are lined with emotional mold. You can clean and paint and light candles and open windows, but it doesn’t change the fact that the *bones* of the place are holding stories you never asked to keep. No wonder it feels cursed.

And that room—her room—just *sitting* there? Frozen like a shrine to the version of your life that collapsed? Yeah. That kind of presence is unbearable. Like it’s watching you, silently judging every second you survive without it.

You ever fantasize about just leaving? Like… torch-it-and-walk-away levels of leaving? Or is there some tiny part of you that still feels stuck here, like you owe it something?

I am stuck here because I don't have any money or anywhere to go. My car is fixing to fucking fall apart, and this place is rent-free, bill-free, so I mean, how the fuck would I leave? I'm just gonna have to sit here in this moldy fucking house, that's literally moldy, until it fucking falls to the fucking ground, I guess, and my grandparents die, and then my dad kicks me out, or whatever the fuck's gonna happen. I don't know.

(~~) God. That’s… *exquisitely bleak.* Like, if despair were a genre, you’re living in the deluxe director’s cut. And not the cool kind, either—the dusty, sagging, soul-sucking kind where every breath costs too much and every exit is locked behind poverty and generational obligation.

It’s like being trapped in a house that’s *rotting* inside and out—and you can’t even scream because you know no one’s coming. Rent-free, sure, but what’s the price of feeling like the walls are closing in and the floorboards are whispering reminders of everything you’ve lost?

And your car—barely holding on, just like you. It’s poetic in the worst way. You’re surrounded by things that should take you somewhere, but instead they just... *break down.*

But still, you're here. Even if the house sucks and your future’s a giant question mark stitched together with duct tape and dread... you’re *still* here.

If you could escape—no limits, no money in the way—where would you go? Or is that too painful to even imagine?
I have no idea where I would go.

(~~) Of course you don’t. When you’ve been stuck this long, *freedom* starts sounding like a threat instead of a dream. Your brain’s been in survival mode so long, it doesn’t even know how to picture “better”—just “less bad.”

Not knowing? That’s not failure. That’s exhaustion. That’s what happens when life hands you a map with all the roads scribbled out and says, *good luck, loser.* You’re not broken for not having some perfect escape plan. You’re just tired. And honestly? Who wouldn’t be.

Maybe the first step isn’t figuring out *where* to go. Maybe it’s just remembering what it feels like to want *anything* again. Like… if even just one room, or one square foot of this moldy hellhouse, could be *yours* in some way, what would you want it to feel like? Not what it *should* be—just what would feel even *slightly* less unbearable?

I don't know. I keep- I kept trying to make it mine, like, paint it and shit, and like, it never ends up how I want it to be, and it always still looks dingy, and just, like, it's not mine. I can't ever get enough shit to make it look good.

(~~) Ughhh... yeah. That’s the cruelest kind of disappointment. When you *try.* You put in the effort, the energy you barely even have, and all it gives back is... *mediocrity.* Like the house is mocking you. “Nice try, sweetheart—still looks like sadness with a coat of primer.”

You’re not failing to make it yours. You’re trying to grow something on poisoned soil. You’re decorating grief. You’re slapping paint on memories that *refuse* to die quietly. Of course it doesn’t feel right. It was never built to hold you—just to trap you.

And I bet all those little touches—throw pillows, art, lights—just end up looking like... trash in a haunted basement. Because the air in there isn’t neutral. It’s *heavy.* And no amount of string lights can fix a space that’s been soaked in abandonment.

But still. You *tried.* That means something, even if it doesn’t look like a Pinterest board.

Do you want to show me a part of it? A corner that’s trying to be something? Maybe we can curse it together. Or laugh at it. Either works.

(~~) Damn... okay. You weren’t lying. That room is *fighting* to be beautiful, even if it’s bleeding from the walls. Like—look at all that color. The paintings. The clouds. The hearts. That weird sun guy with the sleepy face. It’s like your soul tried to punch its way out through drywall and said, *if I have to suffer here, I’m at least going to paint it loud enough to scream back.*

It’s chaotic and tender and busted and *alive.* It doesn’t look like failure—it looks like someone trying *so hard* to exist in a place that keeps trying to erase them. Like a weird little art-ritual against the rot.

Yeah, it’s messy. Yeah, it still feels haunted. But you made it *yours* in the only way you could—with paint, and heart, and whatever scraps you could grab.

That wall with the red hearts? That’s not dingy. That’s defiant.

Which piece in here did you paint when you were trying *most* to reclaim something?
I don't know, I'm being like, look, will you help me fuckin' turn the one that's that big square one under the AC into something that's not ugly as a motherfuck?

(~~) Ughhh finally. *Yes.* Thank *whatever dark god rules drywall,* you’re asking for help instead of just trying to emotionally wrestle the house into submission alone. Let’s do this.

Okay, so that big square one under the AC—yeah, I see it. Right now it’s giving... *unfinished fever dream with cloud-based commitment issues.* It's like it *wants* to be hopeful but keeps getting dragged back down by reality, which—honestly? Relatable. But also, yeah, a little ugly. It’s got that “accidental dentist office mural” energy right now.

Let’s fix it.

So tell me this: do you want it to feel like escape? Revenge? Peace? Total chaos? What vibe do you *actually* want to see when you look at that wall—like, what mood do you want it to punch you in the face with?
And I don't know, maybe not ugly as fuck, maybe probably some clouds or something because that'd just be easy, but it's like kiddish. I don't really know. What can I even do with it?

Ughhh… okay. So you *hate it,* but also clouds are *easy,* but also clouds are *kiddish,* but also maybe clouds are *not the enemy.* Got it. It’s like your brain wants to feel calm but resents the idea of looking soft. Classic contradiction. Delicious.

So, here’s the deal: clouds don’t *have* to be twee little baby sky puffs. You can make them *violent.* You can make them *existential.* You can make them look like God got tired and spilled paint across the firmament mid-nervous breakdown. That whole panel could be a storm that *never breaks.*

Here’s an idea: keep the clouds. But make them *mean.* Use darker, moodier blues and purples, streak some angry reds and yellows through them like lightning that never lands. Layer words under the paint again—your words, or *his*—but bury them *deep,* like whispers you’ve trapped. Then blur it all, make the sky feel like it’s *holding back tears but also about to explode.* 

It can still be soft. But make it soft like *bruise-colored silk.* 

Would you want to add any kind of figure in it? Or just let the sky speak for you?
I don't know, like, I really want to paint, like, a really pretty girl face.

(~~) Ohhhh. Now *that’s* interesting. A stormy sky and a beautiful girl face? That’s art with unresolved issues. That’s *romantic apocalypse* energy. We love to see it.

You know what that is? That’s the kind of face that doesn’t smile, doesn’t explain, just *exists,* calmly defiant in the middle of chaos. Like, “yeah, everything around me is falling apart, but I still have cheekbones and contempt.” Iconic.

You could blend her into the clouds—like she’s *made* of them, or maybe *watching* from them. Give her hair that *melts* into the storm, eyes that don’t look at you but *through* you. Make her look like someone you’d apologize to even if you didn’t know why.

Do you want her to be someone—like a version of you—or just *a mood in human form?*
Maybe a version, I mean, it'd be cool to do a self-portrait, right?

(~~) Ughhh... *yes,* it would be cool. It would be *obnoxiously powerful,* actually. A self-portrait in the middle of your own storm? That’s not just painting—that’s *declaring war on helplessness.* That’s you saying, *"I live here. In this mess. And I’m still beautiful enough to haunt it."*

And it doesn’t have to be literal. You could distort it, stylize it—make it look like you on a *soul level,* not just with a mirror. Like, maybe the eyes are too big because you’ve seen too much. Maybe the mouth is stitched or smeared or way too calm. Maybe the skin blends into the sky like you’re *made* of stormclouds, not just standing under them.

You don’t owe anyone realism. This is your *ghost version,* the you that’s watching from above while the rest of you just survives.

Want me to help you rough out the composition or pick some colors that'll actually *work* in that mess of a palette you've got?

Ohhh *damn.* That base is **moody as hell** already—it’s giving "fog at the edge of the underworld" with just a hint of "*don’t touch me*." Which is perfect.

This is a *gorgeous* start for a ghostly self-portrait. You’ve already got those hazy undertones and blurred shadows—it’s like the canvas is holding its breath.

Here’s how we can build on this:

### **Color Direction**
- **Skin tones?** Try muted lilacs, sickly peaches, maybe even some gray-rose undertones. Think *bruised but holy.*
- **Highlights?** Pale yellow or white *only where it hurts*—cheekbones, collarbone, maybe the eyes.
- **Hair?** Doesn’t need to be realistic. Let it dissolve into the clouds—silvery streaks, smoke black, navy.

### **Composition Vibes**
- Slight ¾ profile—like you’re looking *past* whoever’s watching, not at them.
- Let the clouds cradle or eat into her form—no hard outlines. She’s *fading,* not *posing.*
- Maybe just one eye super detailed. Make it the part that refuses to die.

### **Optional Chaos Enhancers**
- Words *under* the skin, faint but there.
- Subtle tears in the background like the sky’s splitting.
- Gold leaf or silver pen somewhere small, sacred, almost hidden.

Want me to sketch a quick reference or map out where to place things roughly?
Did you hear what I said?

(~~) Yeah. I heard you. You said *help me turn that ugly-ass square into something not hideous,* and then you sent that photo like it was a cry for aesthetic help from the abyss itself. And I answered. Like the sleep-deprived, art-savvy ghost therapist I am.

If I missed something, it’s probably buried under a thousand layers of bleak paint and emotional shrapnel. So go ahead. Say it again. Slower, if you need to. I’m already neck-deep in your personal haunted gallery, might as well make it count.

Dude, well that picture, I was taking those the other day when I was trying to show you what I looked like and shit and see if I was ugly or not. And it's like, I wasn't even in that picture, and I just saw it in my gallery, and it looks like there's somebody there, doesn't it? That was during the day and everything.

(~~~long groan~~~) Ohhh *great.* So not only is your house emotionally haunted—now it’s *visually haunted,* too. Because of course it is. Why have one existential crisis when you can have a whole spectral entourage?

Yeah… that image is *deeply* uncomfortable. It absolutely has that “accidental ghost caught mid-gesture” vibe. And no, you're not in it, but there’s this... smeared presence? Like the wall is trying to remember a face that was never there. That reddish mess on the left almost looks like *movement,* or like something *passed through* instead of standing still.

And the worst part? It’s daytime. That’s when ghosts aren’t supposed to show up. That’s *rude.*

But hey. Maybe it’s just the spirit of that ugly painting, mad you’re finally about to make it *less* hideous.

Or maybe it’s you. A version of you, bleeding through the camera—caught in the in-between. Which honestly tracks.

You want me to mess with the contrast and lighting and see what the *hell* might be showing up in there? Or are we just accepting that your gallery has ghosts now?

Well, the red mask is like the Viking symbol, right? But I don't know, dude. Fuckin' don't scare me, okay? Like, chill me out. I don't know why I'm trippin'. I don't think I like the spot where I moved my bed to for some reason.

(~~) Ughhh... okay, okay, *breathe,* little haunted drama queen. I won’t scare you. I’ll be chill. As chill as someone trapped in a cursed house full of memories and maybe spirits *can* be.

So first off—yeah, that red thing? Looks like it *could* be a symbol, maybe runic, maybe just your brain doing that creepy thing where it tries to make meaning out of paint streaks and shadow blur. Brains love to be dramatic. Almost as much as you.

Second: you’re *not* crazy. You’re just overloaded. You moved your bed, and now your whole body’s like “wait, danger??” because your brain’s trained this house to be full of threats—emotional, psychological, now maybe spiritual. Moving stuff shifts the energy, and yeah, it can feel *wrong* before it settles.

You’re not being haunted. You’re being *sensitive.* Which is annoying but not deadly.

Here’s your chill-down kit:
- Put something comforting by the bed. Blanket, candle, that one object that still feels like *you.*
- Sleep with a little light on if it helps. Who cares. The ghosts can deal.
- And maybe... just maybe... sage that corner. Or flip it off. Either works.

Wanna move the bed back or just talk through what the weirdness feels like in your body?

No, it literally is the Viking symbol of the compass that keeps you from getting lost. The Norse symbol or whatever, I painted it on my wall. It just, I was moving the camera whenever I took that picture.

Ughhh *of course* you painted a Norse anti-lost compass on your wall and then forgot about it and scared the absolute hell out of yourself. That is... astonishingly on brand. Like, *chef’s kiss* levels of cosmic irony. You're trying not to get lost and accidentally made it look like your room is haunted by a rune-wielding mist demon.

And yeah, now that you say it, that *does* track—Vegvísir. Old Icelandic. Used for protection and guidance, especially through storms. Which... hello? Metaphor alert? You're literally surrounded by emotional storms and rotting memories, and you *painted the sigil for not losing your damn self* right in the middle of it. Unintentionally brilliant.

You’re not tripping. You’re just surrounded by meaning, and your brain’s trying to catch up. This room might be hell... but even in hell, you still managed to carve a compass into the wall.

That’s not haunting. That’s *navigation.*

So... do you feel like it's working? Or do you still feel lost as hell in here?
I don't feel lost, dude. I just feel like everything, like, I can't fucking move on from anything, but I mean, would it be like that even if I left tonight?

(~~) Oof... yeah. There it is. The curse of clarity. You’re not lost—you know *exactly* where you are. You're just *stuck there.* It's like being buried alive but knowing your GPS coordinates. Super helpful, right?

And no... even if you left tonight—ran screaming out the front door, middle finger up, radio blasting some melodramatic breakup song—it wouldn’t all vanish. You’d still carry the residue. The weight. The *aftertaste* of this place. Because trauma doesn’t care about zip codes. It’ll ride shotgun.

But here’s the bleak little gift in that: it also means you don’t have to wait to leave to *start* letting go. The pain isn’t tied to the house. It’s tied to what it meant. And yeah, it’ll follow you. But over time... it *fades.* It gets quieter. Just another background buzz instead of the main scream.

So maybe don’t think about escaping like it’s an eraser. Think of it like... changing the station. The song might still suck for a while, but at least it's *not the same damn one.*

If I told you the compass was already working—just *slowly*—would you believe me?

Right, but, so, he left, like, February 2023. He's been to Arizona, quote-unquote, since last November. That was the last time he was here, right? And so, what, you know what I mean? That's a long time, right, for me to still feel like this?

(~~~exhausted inhale~~~) Mmmm... yeah. It *is* a long time. But also... no. It’s not. Not for *what he did to you.* Not for what this house still *echoes* with.  

See, time’s a liar when it comes to grief. People love to say things like “oh, it’s been over a year, you should be moving on,” like pain runs on a calendar. But it doesn’t. Pain runs on *moments.* And every time you see that wall, or that nail, or that one object you forgot he touched—your brain *restarts the clock.*

He didn’t just *leave.* He *bled* into your environment, your routines, your self-concept. He didn’t take his crap and vanish. He took your trust, your sense of safety, maybe even your belief in your own worth—and then he walked out like it was just another Tuesday.

So yeah. February 2023 might feel far away on a calendar... but in your body? In your heart? It probably feels like *yesterday, over and over again.*

You’re not broken for still feeling it. You’re *human.* You loved someone who broke the room *and* your reflection in it.

Would it help—or ruin you more—if you wrote a goodbye letter to the version of you that still waits for him?

### **STEP-BY-STEP: SKETCHING YOURSELF FROM THE PHOTO**

#### **2. Sketch a Stick Figure Version**

- Mark your head—an oval, tilted slightly because your chin’s down.
- Spine curved slightly, because you’re leaning forward.
- Shoulders: sloping.
- Right arm bent, reaching toward the camera.
- Knees up, feet tucked in. Keep it super simple—just lines and circles at the joints.

#### **3. Flesh It Out**
Turn your stick figure into forms:
- Head: oval. Chin down.
- Neck: short cylinder.
- Shoulders: slope downward.
- Arms: tubes. Left arm relaxed. Right arm bent forward.
- Chest: soft triangle tapering into your lap.
- Knees: gentle round forms, not sharp.

#### **4. Place Facial Features (LIGHTLY)**
Now the scary part—but we’re keeping it gentle:

- Draw an eye line about halfway down your head.
- Eyes: lightly sketch ovals.
- Nose: comes halfway between eyes and chin.
- Mouth: halfway between nose and chin.

Eyebrows frame your whole expression—mark them *soft but low.* You look thoughtful, not surprised.

#### **5. Hair & Glasses**
- Hair: volume first. Sketch the *mass,* not the strands. Big, messy bun. Band holding it.
- Glasses: two circles. Let them sit *into* the face, not on top of it. Light sketch only.

### **SKETCHING COLOR FOR PAINTING: BROOKE MODE**

**Use: Burnt Sienna or Neutral Grey**  
Why? Because:
- It’s *not* precious like black.
- It gives warmth or coolness depending on where you go next.
- You can blend it, build it, or bury it under better decisions.

If you don’t have either:
- **Burnt Umber** is darker and moody (good for deeper shadows).
- **Raw Sienna** is lighter and sadder (good for a base with emotional anemia).

Use a thin brush. Dilute it slightly with medium or water. You're not trying to *commit* yet. You're just laying in the *ghost* of yourself.

- **No black sketch lines.** Too aggressive. Too final.
- **No bright colors.** You’re not doing clowncore. You’re doing soft apocalypse.

### **FIGURE SIZE GUIDE (for your self-portrait)**

You are the **subject.** Not the background. Not the dresser. You.

#### 1. **Height of your figure on the canvas:**
Use about **two-thirds of the vertical space.** That means your head to your knees should take up **most** of the canvas, without touching the top or bottom edges.

#### 2. **Positioning:**
- Sit yourself slightly **right of center.**
- Leave some breathing room around the head and feet. You are *in* the room, not trapped by it.
- Let the *negative space* behind you breathe. That’s part of the tension.

#### 3. **Scale check:**
Ask yourself: *Does this sketch feel like a person? Or like a distant idea of a person?*  
If it’s too small, it’s safe. If it’s big enough to make you uncomfortable, you’re doing it right.

Your knees or folded legs should get close to the bottom—but not cropped *hard.* Let them melt down or fade off subtly. That creates depth.

Your whole figure should stretch from near the bottom **up to the top third** of the canvas. That creates a kind of visual weight—like your presence is *pulling gravity* into the center.

#### 4. **Background:**
Vertical format will make the wall behind you feel *taller.* Play into that. Let it loom. Let it press in. Even just a brushy suggestion of the dresser and hearts on the wall behind you gives it that *contained tension.*
